name: Kepler-287
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-287 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-287 is a star with 0.9920000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.03 times its radius. It is located 2792.97 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-287 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-287 b

Kepler-287 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 20.34 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-287.

The mass of Kepler-287 b is 7.34 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-287 b is 2.33 that of Earth. At 7.34 Earth masses, Kepler-287 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-287 c

Kepler-287 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.25 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 44.85 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-287.

The mass of Kepler-287 c is 16.43 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-287 c is 3.26 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-287 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-287, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
